Dry reforming of methane (DRM) has attracted increasing interest due to its ability to transform greenhouse gases, such as CH₄ and CO₂, into useful synthesis gas composed of H₂ and CO. Ni supported on Al₂O₃ is commonly applied in this reaction; however, its activity tends to decline due to sintering and carbon accumulation. This work evaluated how Ce, Mg, Si, and Ti promoters influence Ni/Al2O3, with the goal of improving its catalytic performance in DRM. Four different catalysts were synthesized using equal molar amounts of promoters, and their influence on Ni crystallite size, reduction properties, as well as surface basicity was investigated through various characterization techniques, such as X-ray diffraction, H₂-TPR, and CO₂-TPD analyses. Ni/Ce-Al exhibited the optimal performance in the DRM owing to its small Ni crystallite size, excellent reducibility, and superior CO2 activation capability. Although the other promoted catalysts affected the physicochemical properties of Ni, they did not improve the DRM performance due to their lower reducibility, larger Ni particle size, and diminished CO2 activation ability. This study highlights the promotional effects on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts and provides a pathway for the development of durable DRM catalysts. DRM is regarded as an attractive approach for converting the two main greenhouse gases, methane (CH₄) and carbon dioxide (CO₂), into useful syngas, which consists primarily of hydrogen (H₂) and carbon monoxide (CO), as per Eq. (1). DRM not only mitigates greenhouse gases but also generates high-purity syngas with a nearly 1:1 H2/CO ratio, rendering it an important feedstock for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and methanol production [3–5]. (1) C H 4 + C O 2 ↔ 2 CO + 2 H 2 H 298 K ∘ = 247 kJ · mo l − 1 Considering that DRM involves a strongly endothermic reaction and demands elevated operating temperatures (>700 °C), catalyst stability under harsh reaction conditions is essential [6–8]. Nickel supported on Al₂O₃ has been used due to its affordability and excellent activity, though it remains susceptible to rapid deactivation [9,10]. The main causes of deactivation include sintering of the nickel metal at reaction temperatures above 700 °C and coke deposition due to side-reactions including methane decomposition (Eq. (2)) and the reverse Boudouard reaction (Eq. (3)) [11,12]. (2) C H 4 → C + 2 H 2 H 298 K ∘ = 75 kJ · mo l − 1 (3) 2 CO → C + C O 2 H 298 K ∘ = − 172 kJ · mo l − 1 To overcome these limitations, many researchers have focused on modifying Ni/Al₂O₃ catalysts by incorporating various promoters. One promising strategy for improving the resistance to coke formation is by enhancing the CO₂ activation ability. CO2 activation provides activated oxygen species (O*) that can effectively react with CHx* and C* intermediates, preventing their polymerization into cokes [13]. Alkaline earth promoters, such as Mg and Ca, are known to increase the surface basicity and CO2 adsorption ability of catalysts. Alipour et al. studied the effects of Mg, Ca, and Ba promoters on Ni/Al2O3 in the DRM and found that Mg was the most effective for enhancing the catalytic performance stemming from decreased coke deposition and enhanced Ni reducibility [14–16]. Another approach involves using promoters with oxygen storage capabilities, such as CeO₂ and TiO₂, which can help eliminate coke through the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism [17–20]. Numerous studies have demonstrated the excellent coke resistance of Ce due to its oxygen storage capacity. Chen et al. found that incorporating CeO2 into Ni/Al2O3 catalysts facilitates decomposition of CO2, which forms active surface oxygen species near the Ni particles. These studies suggested that the oxidative environment at the Ni-support interface facilitated the oxidation of carbon species, thereby precluding their nucleation and growth as coke, thus enhancing the coke resistance during the DRM [21–25]. Al2O3 has been utilized as a support material for Ni owing to its high surface area and good thermal stability [26–28]. However, Al2O3 undergoes phase-transformation into various transitional alumina species at the high temperatures that are normally used for the DRM. The phase transition of Al₂O₃ reduces the surface area, causing the Ni particles to sinter. Gao et al. synthesized Ni catalysts supported on various alumina phases (γ-, δ-, θ-, and α-Al₂O₃) and confirmed that as γ-Al₂O₃ gradually transitioned into α-Al₂O₃, Ni interacts more weaker with alumina, leading to larger Ni particle sizes due to Ni sintering [29]. To mitigate these phase transitions, various promoters have been explored for enhancing the thermal stability of Al2O3. Kwak et al. reported that additives such as BaO and La₂O₃ can enhance the thermal stability of γ-Al₂O₃ by covering specific sites on the surface of alumina [30]. Garbarino et al. found that SiO₂ improves the thermal stability of γ-Al₂O₃ [31]. Enhancing the thermal stability of Al₂O₃ via promoters is expected to help maintain the catalyst stability at high reaction temperatures, leading to improved DRM performance. Because promoters influence both the active Ni phases and Al2O3 supports simultaneously, promotional effects should be investigated systematically to clarify these complex relationships and provide deeper insights into their effects on the catalyst performance. This study presents a rigorous comparison of the effects of Ce, Mg, Si, and Ti as promoters by preparing Ni/Al₂O₃ catalysts with each promoter in equimolar amounts. The catalysts are characterized using multiple techniques, and the effects of each promoter on the support stability, metal-support interactions, surface basicity, and DRM performance are evaluated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Identical molar amounts (2.9 mmol) of Ce, Ti, Mg, and Si (9.2, 3.4, 1.7, 2.0 wt % respectively) were each supported on γ-Al2O3 (PURALOX SBa200, Sasol) using incipient wetness impregnation. The metal precursors used were cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Sigma-Aldrich), magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, Junsei), tetraethyl orthosilicate (Si(OC2H5)4, Sigma-Aldrich), and tetra isopropyl titanate (Ti{OCH(CH3)2}4, Junsei). Synthesized supports were calcined in a muffle furnace (R-1400mini, Hantech) at 900 °C for 4 h and labeled as Al and P-Al (P = Ce, Mg, Si, Ti). Nickel-supported catalysts were synthesized via the incipient wetness impregnation technique using nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO₃)₂·6H₂O, Sigma-Aldrich), with a nickel content of 10 wt %. The impregnated samples were subjected to calcination in air (100 mL/min) at 800 °C for 2 h in a quartz tubular reactor. Following this step, the catalysts underwent reduction in a 10 % H₂/N₂ stream (90 mL/min) at 750 °C for 2 h, followed by purging under N₂ at 400 °C for 30 min. The resulting materials were designated as Ni/Al and Ni/P-Al, where P refers to Ce, Mg, Si, or Ti. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed using an X’Pert³ Powder diffractometer (Malvern PANalytical) equipped with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å), operated at 40 eV and 30 mA. Samples were scanned over a 2θ range of 10 ° to 80 ° at a scan rate of 2 °/min. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis was obtained using an Autosorb-iQ system (Quantachrome). The samples were pre-treated at 150 °C for 6 h and then N₂ adsorption–desorption measurements were obtained at 77 K. High-resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) combined with energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) was performed on a JEM-F200 microscope (JEOL) operated at 200 kV. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H₂-TPR) was conducted in a quartz reactor equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 50 mg of each sample was pre-treated at 500 °C under 20 % O₂/Ar (60 mL/min), cooled to ambient temperature, then purged with Ar. H₂-TPR profiles were measured under 2 % H₂/Ar (60 mL/min) with ramping from room temperature to 900 °C at 10 °C/min using a YL6500 GC (TCD only, without column), with moisture generated during reduction removed by a 4 Å molecular sieve. For CO₂ temperature-programmed desorption (CO₂-TPD), reduced samples (50 mg) were pretreated at 500 °C under 2 % H₂/Ar (60 mL/min) for 30 min, then purged with Ar for 30 min and cooled to 50 °C. CO₂ was adsorbed with a 30 % CO₂/Ar mixture (30 mL/min) for 30 min, followed by Ar purging (45 mL/min) to eliminate physisorbed CO₂. Desorption was monitored up to 750 °C with the ramping rate of 10 °C/min, using the FID detector of a YL6500 GC system. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on an SDT650 instrument (TA Instruments). Pretreatment was performed at 150 °C under N₂ for 20 min to remove moisture, then cooled to room temperature. Measurements were performed in air (50 mL/min) with temperature ramping to 1000 °C at 10 °C/min. Raman spectra were obtained using an NRS-5100 spectrometer (JASCO) with a 532 nm excitation laser in the range of 1000–3500 cm⁻¹. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The dry reforming of methane (DRM) was conducted at ambient pressure in a fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor. The catalysts were pelletized and physically mixed with inert SiO₂ (silica gel, 200–425 mesh, Sigma-Aldrich) in a 1:1 wt ratio. For each run, 45 mg of catalyst pellets within the 35–80 mesh range were used. The samples were pre-reduced under 10 % H₂/Ar (90 mL/min) at 700 °C for 30 min, followed by argon purging (81 mL/min) for 30 min. After this pretreatment step, a CH₄/CO₂ gas mixture (1:1 vol ratio) was introduced with a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 53,000 mL·g⁻¹·h⁻¹. Reaction products were cooled in a condenser to remove moisture before entering the gas chromatograph (YL6500, YOUNGIN Chromass), equipped with Porapak N and Molsieve 13X columns for gas separation. The concentrations of CH₄, CO₂, H₂, and CO were quantified using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The conversions of methane and carbon dioxide, as well as the H₂/CO ratio, were calculated according to the following equations: Methane conversion : X CH 4 ( % ) = C H 4 , IN − C H 4 , OUT C H 4 , IN × 100 Carbon dioxide conversion : X CO 2 ( % ) = C O 2 , IN − C O 2 , OUT C O 2 , IN × 100 H 2 / CO ratio : H 2 / CO = H 2 yield CO yield = H 2 , OUT / 2 C H 4 , IN C O OUT / ( C H 4 , IN + C O 2 , IN ) in which X IN and X OUT denote the molar flow of X in and out, respectively [32]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Al and P-Al Ni/Al₂O₃ catalysts were prepared with Ce, Mg, Si, and Ti promoters to study how these additives influence the physicochemical characteristics of catalysts applied in DRM. The bulk structure of Al and P-Al was investigated using XRD (Fig. 1 (A)). The main peaks in the spectrum of bare Al2O3 (Al) correspond to the δ-Al2O3 (JCPDS# 47–1770), as indicated by the distinct peak splitting in the 2θ ranges of 31–34 ° and 44–48 °, which suggests that γ-Al2O3 was transformed into δ-Al2O3 as a result of 900 °C calcination [33]. The diffraction peaks of Ti-Al aligned with those seen in Al, implying that Ti incorporation did not hinder the γ to δ phase transformation. Furthermore, no diffraction peaks corresponding to TiO2 (anatase or rutile) were observed, suggesting that TiO2 was well dispersed on the Al2O3 surface. Similarly, no SiO₂ phase was detected in Si-Al due to the good dispersion and amorphous nature of SiO₂. The XRD pattern of Si-Al maintained characteristic peaks of γ-Al₂O₃ even after 900 °C calcination, suggesting that SiO₂ suppressed the phase transformation from γ- to δ-Al₂O₃. This stabilization effect is because SiO₂ occupies specific surface sites on Al₂O₃ to hinder the phase transition, as reported on BaO and La₂O₃ additives [30]. This observation further demonstrates that TiO2 and SiO2 behave differently when dispersed on the γ-Al2O3 surface. For Mg-Al, peaks at 2θ = 19.4 °, 37.3 °, 45.8 °, and 66.7 ° became more pronounced, indicating the formation of MgAl2O4 (JCPDS# 073–1959) spinel. The absence of MgO peaks at 2θ = 43.0 ° and 62.4 ° suggests that Mg predominantly existed in the form of MgAl2O4 spinel rather than MgO [34]. The phase of alumina in Mg-Al could not be clearly identified because of overlap of the peaks with those of the spinel. For Ce-Al, peaks of the CeO2 phase were clearly observed, and the crystallite size measured along the (111) plane was 10 nm. STEM analysis (Fig. S1) showed that two types of CeO2 particles existed on Ce-Al. The first (Fig. S1(A, B)) consists of cubic or rod-shaped, large CeO2 particles (>30 nm), which agglomerated due to the high calcination temperature; the other (Fig. S1(C, D)) consists of well-dispersed CeO₂ clusters with an average size around 5 nm. These findings clearly demonstrate the presence of CeO2 particles with distinct size differences on Ce-Al. Due to overlap with the CeO₂ peaks, the phase of Al₂O₃ was difficult to distinguish. The surface area and porosity of Al and P-Al were characterized through BET analysis. Fig. S2 presents the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and Fig. S3 presents the pore size distribution. Table 1 shows a summary of surface areas and pore volumes. All samples showed type IV isotherms with a noticeable type H1 hysteresis loop. The surface area of Ti-Al (160 m2/g) and Mg-Al (170 m2/g) was smaller than that of Al (180 m2/g). In contrast, Ce-Al (239 m2/g) and Si-Al (216 m2/g) exhibited increased surface areas. Pore size distribution (Fig. S3) showed that Si-Al maintained a similar pore size distribution to bare Al, but with increased pore volume at ∼60 nm, indicating that phase stabilization of alumina as γ-phase primarily contributes to high BET surface areas [35]. On the other hand, Ce-Al showed additional mesopores in the 10–20 nm range and increased pore volume in the 50–80 nm region. Considering the existence of separate CeO2 particles, evidenced by XRD and STEM, separate CeO₂ particles additionally increased the surface area. Meanwhile, improving thermal stability of alumina via ceria would also contribute the surface area increase [36], although we could not clearly distinguish the alumina phases from XRD. CO2-TPD analysis was carried out to examine the effect of the promoters on the surface basicity of Al2O3. All samples showed a peak near 108 °C (Fig. 1(B)). The CO2 adsorption amounts were quantified and are summarized in Table 1 and Fig. 1C. Mg-Al exhibited the highest CO2 adsorption of 50 μmol/g, significantly higher than that of Al (25 μmol/g). These results are consistent with previous studies, which showed that Mg enhances the surface basicity of Ni-based catalysts [34]. CeO2 also enhanced the CO2 adsorption up to 46 μmol/g, which can be attributed to the oxygen vacancies on the CeO2 surface, which serve as active sites for CO2 activation [37]. The amount of CO2 adsorbed on Ti-Al was similar to that on Al, whereas Si-Al demonstrated reduced CO2 adsorption. The basicity of Si-Al decreased because SiO2 would reduce hydroxyl groups on the Al2O3 surface, available for CO2 adsorption [38]. The order of the surface basicity can be summarized as follows: Mg-Al > Ce-Al > Ti-Al = Al > Si-Al, indicating that the type of promoter plays a key role in modifying the surface basicity of the support. In overall, XRD, BET, and CO2 TPD results clearly demonstrate each promoter affects the bulk structure and surface properties of the Al2O3 support. 3.2 Characterization of Ni/P-Al A series of Ni/P-Al catalysts was synthesized to study the effect of the promoter on the Ni phases and their interactions with the support. Fig. 2 presents the XRD patterns of Ni/P-Al after calcination and reduction. Fig. 2(A) shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts calcined at 800 °C. Ni/Al and Ni/Ti-Al showed no diffraction peaks of the NiO, whereas the intensity of the peaks at 2θ = 37 °, 45 °, and 66 ° became more intense than bare Al, indicating the formation of NiAl2O4. This observation suggests that resulting from the high calcination temperature of 800 °C, Ni species exist solely as NiAl2O4 rather than as NiO. Although a similar pattern was observed for Ni/Mg-Al, the formation of NiAl2O4 was difficult to confirm as the peaks overlap with MgAl2O4. In particular, for Ni/Si-Al, the NiO phase was observed along with NiAl2O4. These results are in line with the work of Garbarino et al. to report that SiO2 competes with Ni for spinel formation sites in Al2O3, thereby hindering NiAl2O4 formation and promoting NiO formation [31]. For Ni/Ce-Al, the Ni species predominantly existed as NiAl2O4. Notably, crystallite size changes in the CeO2 promoter were obvious after Ni loading and calcination. Considering that the crystallite size of CeO2 was 10 nm for Ce-Al, the crystallite size of CeO2 increased drastically to 30 nm for Ni/Ce-Al. Marinho et al. reported that after Ni loading and calcination at 800 °C, CeO2 segregated from Al2O3 and the particle sizes of CeO2 increased [25]. Interestingly, this trend is opposite to that observed for Ni/Si-Al. In the case of Ni/Si-Al, Si occupied specific sites on Al2O3 despite the presence of Ni, thereby inhibiting the formation of NiAl2O4. In contrast, for Ni/Ce-Al, Ni displaced CeO2 on the Al2O3 surface, leading to the aggregation of CeO2 clusters, as evidenced by the XRD results. Fig. 2(B) shows the XRD patterns of the reduced Ni/P-Al. For all samples, the diffraction peak at 38 ° was less intense than that of the calcined samples, and the NiO peak observed for calcined Ni/Si-Al disappeared after reduction. These changes imply that NiAl₂O₄ and NiO were reduced into metallic Ni (JCPDS# 04–0580), which is supported by the presence of diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44 °, 52 °, and 76 °. The Ni crystallite sizes were summarized in Table 2 . The Ni crystallite size was the smallest for Ni/Ce-Al (10 nm), which is attributed to the large specific surface area of the Ce-Al support, as indicated by the BET analysis. The crystallite size of Ni/Ti-Al was significantly larger (18 nm) than other catalysts, likely due to shrinkage of the surface area of the Ti–Al support. The crystallite sizes of the other samples were similar to those of bare Ni/Al, ranging from 11 to 13 nm. STEM and EDS mapping were used to identify the Ni particle size and the distribution of Ni and the promoters, as shown in Figs. 3 and S4. The HAADF images and Ni particle size distributions of the reduced samples are shown in Figs. 3 and S4, and the average Ni particle sizes are listed in Table 2. The Ni particle sizes measured from the STEM images were slightly larger than those obtained from XRD, but the trend remained consistent, with the smallest particles observed for Ni/Ce-Al (13.0 nm) and the largest for Ni/Ti-Al (23.5 nm). The EDS map in Fig. S5 shows the distribution of Ni and the promoters. Ni/Ce-Al comprised large CeO2 particles (∼100 nm). However, Mg was highly dispersed owing to the formation of MgAl2O4, as confirmed by XRD. SiO2 and TiO2 were also well-dispersed on Al2O3, which is consistent with the XRD results. Overall, the promoters (Ti, Ce, Si, and Mg) interacted with the Ni and alumina supports in different manners, thus affecting the active phase Ni (NiO or NiAl2O4) and the corresponding particle sizes. The reduction behaviors of the Ni/P-Al were examined using H2-TPR, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . For Ni/Al (Fig. 4A), only the peak attributed to the reduction of NiAl2O4 (>700 °C) was observed, without any reduction peaks of NiO (<700 °C) [39]. The Ce-Al support showed a peak near 400 °C, corresponding to the reduction of surface CeO2, and another above 800 °C, associated with the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ in the bulk phase [24]. However, after incorporating Ni, a new peak appeared in the 200–400 °C range, likely due to the reduction of adsorbed oxygen. Shan et al. reported the formation of a Ni-CeOx solid solution upon incorporating Ni2+ into CeO2, along with the generation of oxygen vacancies on the CeO2 surface and enhanced oxygen adsorption [40]. The second peak in the 450–650 °C range corresponds to the reduction of surface CeO2, similar to that of the Ce-Al support. The third peak above 700 °C shifted to a lower temperature, and its area increased in the profile of Ni/Ce-Al compared to that for Ni/Al. This change originated from both the enhanced reducibility of NiAl2O4 and the reduction of bulk CeO2. The reduction temperature of Ni/Mg-Al was higher than that of Ni/Al. Previous studies have reported that high calcination temperatures (>800 °C) lead to the formation of a solid solution between NiO and MgAl2O4, thereby increasing the reduction temperature [41,42]. The similar shift observed herein for Ni/Mg-Al suggests the formation of a solid solution of NiO and MgAl2O4. Due to the decreased reducibility, the H2 consumption of Ni/Mg-Al decreased drastically to 1190 μmol/g compared to that of Ni/Al (1523 μmol/g). Both Ni/Si-Al (Fig. 4C) and Ni/Ti-Al (Fig. 4D) exhibited lower reduction peak temperatures (at 875 °C and 855 °C, respectively) compared to that of Ni/Al (above 900 °C). The profile of Ni/Si-Al exhibited an asymmetric peak in the 600–900 °C range. To better understand the asymmetrical reduction profile of Ni/Si-Al, H2-TPR analysis of both Ni/Si-Al and Ni/Ti-Al was performed in detail by controlling the ramping rates; the results are presented in Fig. S6. The profile of Ni/Si-Al exhibited a shoulder peak around 750 °C, whereas that of Ni/Ti-Al showed only a single peak. Considering that XRD analysis of Ni/Si-Al confirmed the presence of NiO, the shoulder peak of Ni/Si-Al can be attributed to the reduction of NiO. Thus, SiO2 inhibits the formation of NiAl2O4 and promotes the formation of NiO, which are reduced easily, whereas TiO2 primarily lowers the reduction temperature of NiAl2O4 itself. To assess the actual reducibility, remaining NiAl2O4 species were analyzed by H2-TPR analysis of the reduced catalysts (Fig. S7). Ni/Ce-Al exhibited the highest reducibility, with a reduction of 86 %. Both Ni/Si-Al (78 %) and Ni/Ti-Al (81 %) showed increased reducibility compared to that of Ni/Al (68 %). Finally, Ni/Mg-Al exhibited significantly lower reducibility, with a reduction degree of 51 %, which aligns with the trend observed in the H2-TPR results of calcined samples. These findings indicate that the reduction behavior of the Ni species is strongly influenced by various promoters. To further evaluate the reducibility of the promoters, H2-TPR was conducted on the P-Al supports. Among all samples, only the Ce-Al support exhibited clear reduction peaks in the range of 400–900 °C, corresponding to the stepwise reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+. These results indicate that CeO2 is the only promoter with intrinsic reducibility under the tested conditions. Since the presence of oxygen vacancies in ceramic materials is closely related to their reduction behavior, it can be inferred that reduced CeO2 possesses a significant amount of oxygen vacancies. This property distinguishes CeO2 from other promoters and may play a key role in enhancing the stability of the catalyst during the DRM reaction. In the DRM, basic sites play a crucial role by adsorbing and activating acidic CO2 species on the support surface, thereby suppressing carbon deposition and enhancing the catalyst stability. The CO2 activation abilities of Ni/Al and Ni/P-Al reduced at 750 °C was assessed from the CO2-TPD data (Fig. 5 ). Among the samples, the Ni/Ce-Al catalyst demonstrated the highest CO2 activation capacity, with an adsorption amount of 97 μmol/g. Ni/Mg-Al also exhibited a higher CO₂ adsorption capacity (43 μmol/g) compared to Ni/Al (30 μmol/g), whereas Ni/Si-Al and Ni/Ti-Al had a lower CO₂ adsorption capacity (17 μmol/g and 18 μmol/g, respectively). To analyze the changes in the surface basicity after Ni incorporation and reduction, the CO2-TPD profiles of the reduced catalysts were compared with those of the bare supports (Fig. 5(B)). Notably, the CO2 adsorption of the reduced Ni/Ce-Al was more than double that of the Ce-Al, whereas the adsorption levels of the other samples were comparable to that of the bare support. This dramatic difference suggests that the increased CO2 adsorption capacity of Ni/Ce-Al cannot be attributed solely to the incorporation of Ni, but is strongly influenced by the reduction of CeO2, which forms more surface oxygen vacancies. When the reduction temperature of Ni/Ce-Al was controlled from 600 to 900 °C, the CO2-TPD profiles (Fig. S8) showed a gradual increase in CO2 adsorption with increasing reduction temperature, suggesting that the reduction of CeO2 played a significant role in enhancing the CO2 activation capacity. Each promoter had distinct effects on the reducibility, Ni particle size, and CO₂ adsorption capacity of the Ni-based catalysts. The Ce promoter significantly enhanced the reducibility while maintaining small Ni particle sizes and greatly improving the CO₂ adsorption capacity. Mg had a minimal impact on the Ni particle size and decreased the reducibility. Si increased the reducibility but suppressed CO₂ adsorption. Ti improved the reducibility but resulted in larger Ni particles and a lower CO₂ adsorption capacity compared to that of Ni/Al. These findings suggest that each promoter influences the physicochemical properties of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst in a different manner. 3.3 Catalytic performance in dry reforming of methane To evaluate the effect of the various promoters on the catalyst performance in the DRM, the reaction was evaluated using Ni/Al and Ni/P-Al at 650 °C (CH4:CO2 = 1:1, WHSV = 53,300 ml·g⁻¹·h⁻¹) for 24 h (Fig. 6 ). All samples exhibited H2/CO ratios below 1.0, which can be attributed to the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS, Eq. (4)) side-reaction. Ni/Ce-Al afforded the highest H2/CO ratio of 0.88, whereas Ni/Mg-Al afforded the lowest ratio (0.83), and the other samples presented similar values (0.86) [43]. Furthermore, the H2/CO ratio gradually decreased throughout the reaction due to continuous catalyst deactivation, and Ni/Ce-Al maintained the highest value at the end. The initial CH4 and CO2 conversions of Ni/Al were 59.6 % and 66.6 %, respectively. Among the promoted catalysts, Ni/Ce-Al exhibited the highest initial CH4 and CO2 conversions of 60.8 % and 70.2 %, respectively, whereas Ni/Mg-Al exhibited the lowest values of 51.6 % and 57.2 %, respectively. Ni/Si-Al showed comparable performance to Ni/Al, with CH4 and CO2 conversions of 57.5 % and 64.6 %, respectively, whereas Ni/Ti-Al displayed slightly lower values of 55.1 % and 61.0 %, respectively. The initial catalytic activity in the DRM is proportional to the surface exposure of the Ni species, which serve as active sites [12]. The surface exposure of metallic Ni is influenced by both the Ni particle size and the reducibility of the catalyst. Therefore, the highest initial activity of Ni/Ce-Al originated from the small Ni particle size and excellent reducibility. In contrast, the lowest initial activity exhibited by Ni/Mg-Al stems from its significantly lower reducibility, as confirmed by the H2-TPR results. Ni/Ti-Al exhibited a lower initial activity than Ni/Al, despite the better reducibility of the former. This unusual correlation between the initial conversion and reducibility is primarily originate from the decreased surface area of the support, which led to the formation of larger Ni particles than in Ni/Al. Ni/Ce-Al exhibited significantly improved stability, where the CH4 and CO2 conversion decreased by only 9.8 % and 12.9 %, respectively. In contrast, the other catalysts showed no significant improvement and experienced dramatic deactivation during the first 5 h. Previous studies have highlighted the importance of CO2 activation in suppressing carbon deposition [22,34]. In the DRM, CO2 serves as the oxygen source, and its effective activation can substantially enhance the coke resistance. Based on the CO2-TPD results, the excellent stability of Ni/Ce-Al is attributed to its ability to activate CO2. Moreover, the oxygen storage capacity of CeO2 enabled effective absorption of oxygen from CO2, thereby facilitating coke oxidation and contributing to the superior stability of Ni/Ce-Al. 3.4 Characterization of spent catalyst To identify the underlying reasons of catalyst deactivation, the spent catalysts retrieved after 24 h of reaction were characterized via multiple techniques such as XRD, STEM, TGA, and Raman spectroscopy. Fig. 7 (A) shows the XRD patterns of the spent Ni/P-Al catalysts. A new peak corresponding to graphite (JCPDS# 08–0415) appeared around 2θ = 26° in the spectrum of all samples, indicating coke deposition during the reaction. The intensities of the carbon peaks for the promoted catalysts were lower than those for Ni/Al, indicating reduced formation of graphitic coke on the promoted catalysts. To assess the degree of sintering during the reaction, the Ni crystallite sizes were measured, and the results are summarized in Table 2. Ni/Al maintained an average Ni particle size of 12 nm after the reaction, whereas Ni/Ce-Al and Ni/Si-Al exhibited smaller particle sizes (10 nm). Ni/Mg-Al and Ni/Ti-Al exhibited particle sizes of 11 and 13 nm, respectively. Under the present reaction conditions, the Ni particle sizes did not increase compared to those of the fresh Ni catalysts (10–18 nm). The STEM results are shown in Figs. 8 and S9. The average Ni particle size was 15.0, 11.1, 15.5, 15.6, and 22.0 nm for Ni/Al, Ni/Ce-Al, Ni/Mg-Al, Ni/Si-Al, and Ni/Ti-Al, respectively. The STEM images and particle size distributions also showed no increase in the Ni particle size after the reaction, supporting the XRD results. These results indicate that catalyst deactivation is not due to sintering, but is primarily caused by coke deposition Table 3 . TGA was carried out in air to investigate the extent of coke accumulation on spent catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 7(B). All samples exhibited a weight gain of approximately 1 % in the range of 350–500 °C due to the oxidation of metallic Ni to NiO. The weight gain of Ni/Ce-Al was higher than other samples, which can be attributed to the oxygen storage capacity of CeO2 and its high reducibility. In contrast, Ni/Mg-Al exhibited the lowest weight gain due to the lower exposure of Ni metal, which stemmed from the poor reducibility of Ni. Above 500 °C, all the samples experienced weight loss due to the combustion of coke. The weight loss followed the trend: Ni/Al > Ni/Ti-Al > Ni/Ce-Al > Ni/Si-Al > Ni/Mg-Al. Thus, the degree of coke deposition followed the order: Ni/Al > Ni/Ti-Al > Ni/Ce-Al > Ni/Si-Al > Ni/Mg-Al. Ni/Mg-Al exhibited the highest coke resistance but underwent severe deactivation in the catalyst stability test. Based on these results, the low coke deposition on Ni/Mg-Al can be attributed to its limited Ni exposure rather than its ability to activate CO2. Interestingly, only Ni/Ce-Al exhibited early coke combustion at 500 °C, in contrast to all other samples, where coke combusted after 600 °C. This early coke combustion is considered to have contributed to the superior stability of Ni/Ce-Al. Note that the total amount of deposited coke on Ni/Ce-Al was comparable to that on Ni/Si-Al and Ni/Ti-Al. Ni/Ce-Al showed significantly higher CH₄ conversion over 24 h of reaction than other catalysts, indicating that Ni/Ce-Al was exposed to more harsh condition. Thus, similar coke deposition under harsh conditions demonstrates the superior coke resistance of Ni/Ce-Al. The TGA profiles of Ni/Si-Al and Ni/Ti-Al were comparable to those of Ni/Al, which reflects the low CO2 adsorption capacities. The coke deposition was further analyzed using Raman spectroscopy to investigate the early coke combustion in Ni/Ce-Al. To evaluate the proportion of amorphous to graphitic carbon, the ID/IG ratio was obtained from Raman spectra based on the D band at 1350 cm⁻¹ and the G band at 1580 cm⁻¹ [44]. Raman spectra and the calculated ID/IG values are shown in Fig. 7(C). The ID/IG ratio of Ni/Al was 1.77. The ID/IG values of the Ni/P-Al catalysts were in the range of 1.69–1.83. The coke combustion at a lower temperature (500 °C) in Ni/Ce-Al might originate from the amorphous nature of the deposited coke, or neighboring oxygen from CeO2, which facilitates the combustion of graphitic carbon. Interestingly, the ID/IG ratios of all the samples were almost identical, indicating the similar nature of deposited coke on each catalyst. Therefore, the early oxidation of coke on Ni/Ce-Al at 500 °C is not due to its amorphous nature, but rather a contribution of the oxygen storage capacity of Ni/Ce-Al. Overall, the findings from TGA, Raman analysis, STEM, and XRD indicate that the main cause of catalyst deactivation was coke accumulation, not Ni sintering. Coke removal from Ni/Ce-Al occurred in the low-temperature range (>500 °C), which can be attributed to the oxygen storage capacity of CeO₂. The outstanding catalytic stability of Ni/Ce-Al stems from its exceptional CO2 activation ability and capacity to store and utilize the oxygen derived from activated CO2. 4 Conclusions Promotional effects of Ce, Mg, Si, and Ti additives on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were studied, along with the performance of the promoted catalysts in the DRM. The findings highlight the effect of these promoters on the physicochemical properties of Ni-based catalysts, including the Ni particles size, reducibility, metal-support interactions, and surface basicity, which are crucial for durable DRM catalysts. Ni/Ce-Al exhibited the superior stability, attributed to the enhanced CO2 activation and oxygen storage capacity provided by CeO2, whereas the other catalysts did not exhibit significantly improved DRM performance. Although Ni/Mg-Al displayed the lowest coke deposition, its DRM activity was hindered by poor Ni exposure due to its decreased reducibility. Ni/Si-Al and Ni/Ti-Al exhibited improved reducibility; however, the decreased CO2 activation capability of both catalysts and the significantly larger Ni particle size in Ni/Ti-Al hindered the catalytic performance in the DRM. These results provide valuable insights into the roles of various promoters in Ni-based DRM catalysts and offer a pathway for designing more efficient and durable catalysts for industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Dry reforming of methane (DRM) has attracted increasing interest due to its ability to transform greenhouse gases, such as CH₄ and CO₂, into useful synthesis gas composed of H₂ and CO. Ni supported on Al₂O₃ is commonly applied in this reaction; however, its activity tends to decline due to sintering and carbon accumulation. This work evaluated how Ce, Mg, Si, and Ti promoters influence Ni/Al2O3, with the goal of improving its catalytic performance in DRM. Four different catalysts were synthesized using equal molar amounts of promoters, and their influence on Ni crystallite size, reduction properties, as well as surface basicity was investigated through various characterization techniques, such as X-ray diffraction, H₂-TPR, and CO₂-TPD analyses. Ni/Ce-Al exhibited the optimal performance in the DRM owing to its small Ni crystallite size, excellent reducibility, and superior CO2 activation capability. Although the other promoted catalysts affected the physicochemical properties of Ni, they did not improve the DRM performance due to their lower reducibility, larger Ni particle size, and diminished CO2 activation ability. This study highlights the promotional effects on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts and provides a pathway for the development of durable DRM catalysts.
